repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Support for the Social
            Development Agency Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Support for the Social
            Development Agency Project for Morocco were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: ADS
            (Agence de Developpement Social - Social Development Agency)
            has repositioned its role in participatory diagnostic and
            planning, capacity building of local actors, and income
            generating activities. A clearer Government support for this
            'niche' could help equip the agency with the
            resources that will be needed to maximize its impact on
            poverty. The social agenda is large and complex. Several
            entities and/or programs can be the implementing vehicles
            but their roles and responsibilities need to be
            well-delineated, promoting coherence/complementary of
            interventions and avoiding overlap. The lack of attention to
            the monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system during
            preparation and the early stage of supervision prevent a
            full assessment of the cost effectiveness of ADS'
            approaches to community participation or capacity building
            of local actors. A strengthened M&E system is also
            necessary to produce the analysis that can justify ADS'
            institutionalization in the territorial development/poverty
            alleviation agenda by substantiating its areas of strengths.
            To do so, it will be important that ADS quickly revise its
            M&E framework and adapt it to its new areas of focus.
            Finally, Bank technical support to the impact evaluation
            should have been better planned to influence the quality of
            the evaluation. Social fund projects should be supervised by
            social fund specialists. This helps projects benefit from
            all the knowledge on social funds accumulated by the Bank in
            the last 20 years and from the tools that have been
            developed. It ensures that critical dimensions of social
            funds are not missed during supervision. The project
            benefited from an excellent exposure to international
            experience during preparation when the project was managed
            by a social fund specialist, but less so during supervision.

5086379.trustfund:
TF026821-PHRD-MOROCCO: SOCIAL
            DEVELOPMENT AGENCY,TF054628-PHRD-MOROCCO: SUPPORT FOR THE
            SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT AGENCY PROJECT
5086379.majtheme: Rural development,Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Development Agency Project
            addresses two of the four main core objectives of the
            Country Assistance Strategy, i.e., to develop and strengthen
            participative, and decentralized programs to reduce poverty,
            and fight exclusion, and, to reduce vulnerability of the
            poor especially in rural areas. The main components will: 1)
            support subprojects that enhance the social infrastructure
            of selected poor rural, and urban slum areas, to be based on
            demand, and, will cover areas from basic education, and
            primary health care, to literacy activities, and rural
            drinking water. This should include activities such as
            construction, as well as training, to help communities
            coordinate the infrastructure maintenance and operation; 2)
            support those subprojects enhancing the economic
            infrastructure in rural and urban slum areas, e.g.,
            irrigation, small markets, and rural roads. Subprojects
            financing training and non-financial support, of activities
            directly creating employment opportunities, or expanding
            micro, or small business, or, that finance operations to new
            geographical areas, will also be supported: 3) support the
            capacity of the Social Development Agency's (SDA)
            intermediaries, to identify, appraise, and implement
            subprojects; and, capacity building to selected, local
            nongovernmental organizations will be supported, by
            assessing, and implementing local development projects; and,
            4) finance studies on institutional, and operational aspects
            of SDA, as well as on enhancing its management, and
            understanding of specific technical areas, i.e., micro-finance.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Social Development Agency Project
            : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Social Development
            Agency Project are to develop communities, and social
            infrastructure, support economic infrastructure and income
            generation, develop institutional capacity, and, provide
            support to the institutional, and operational aspects,
            through relevant studies. The potential for environmental
            adversity lies basically during construction, and operation
            of roads, schools, health care centers, and water supply,
            and sanitation systems. This environmental management plan
            stipulates that subprojects, with potentially irreversible
            negative impacts, will not be approved for funding, namely,
            those requiring terracing for a high percentage of slope
            lands; those requiring deforestation, or affecting natural
            habitats and biodiversity; those affecting cultural heritage
            sites; and, those requiring the use of pesticides and
            herbicides. Mitigation calls for measures as follows.
            Ditches and outlets will be maintained to control clogging
            of naturally damaged channels, while drainage facilities
            will be functional to appropriately conduct storm water
            drainage. Site locations should be selected for disposal of
            excavated soil, and, re-vegetation practices along road
            sides, etc., would combat erosion. Water contamination, and
            degradation of water quality, will undergo regular quality
            tests, surveyed according to local water regulations, and
            management practices. Priority will be given to
            rehabilitating toilets, and sanitary installations to
            control improper wastes disposal, including medical wastes,
            and to prevent water borne diseases. Aforestation through
            new techniques, and the use of renewable energy sources,
            will be introduced to control grazing, and deforestation.
